pain_points_original.title: Strict Security & Privacy Compliance
pain_points_original.description: The DPC faces the critical challenge of ensuring AI tools strictly adhere to "Applicable ICT, Security and Cyber policies" and "South Australian Information Privacy Principles (IPPs)." They must solve the problem of safeguarding sensitive government data against cyber risks and privacy breaches.

pain_points_original.title: Integration with Legacy Government Systems
pain_points_original.description: A key technical hurdle is ensuring new AI solutions offer sufficient "maturity, scalability, and adaptability" for "integration into existing government systems." The DPC needs to solve the complexity of connecting modern AI tools with established public sector infrastructure and third-party offerings.

pain_points_original.title: Governance of LLM & Third-Party AI Risks
pain_points_original.description: The DPC must mitigate specific risks associated with "large language models (LLMs)" and their integration. They need to solve the problem of governing data flows in third-party integrations, guided by "Guideline-13.1-Use-of-Large-Language-Model-AI-Tools-Utilities.pdf" to prevent data leakage.

pain_points_original.title: Enhancing Service Delivery Efficiency
pain_points_original.description: The Department needs to solve the problem of operational inefficiency. They are seeking tools specifically to "boost efficiency, inform decision-making" and "improve service delivery" to achieve better "community outcomes" and increase public satisfaction, rather than just adopting tech for tech's sake.

pain_points_original.title: Budgetary Uncertainty for Future Procurement
pain_points_original.description: The DPC currently lacks clear financial benchmarks for AI implementations. They need to solve the problem of undefined costs by obtaining "indicative costing models and pricing structures" to accurately inform "future procurement planning and budget allocation" starting in 2026.
